front.question: The phrenic nerves control the diaphragm and exit the spinal cord at:

choices: is caused by penetrating chest trauma.
is commonly caused by blunt chest trauma.
heals on its own without any treatment.
front.question: A simple pneumothorax:
front.source: See Complications and Management of Chest Injuries

cards.back: is commonly caused by blunt chest trauma.

choices: has most likely experienced a ruptured aorta.
is most likely experiencing severe blood loss.
should be placed in Trendelenburg’s position.
front.question: A patient who presents with profound cyanosis following a chest injury:

choices: excess carbon dioxide will be eliminated.
front.question: If a person’s tidal volume decreases, but his or her respiratory rate remains unchanged:
Which of the following organs or structures does not reside within the mediastinum?
A rapid, irregular pulse following blunt trauma to the chest is most suggestive of a:

choices: often breathes at a slower rate because of lung damage caused by the injury.
will eliminate more carbon dioxide than if he or she were breathing deeply.
must increase his or her respiratory rate to maintain adequate minute volume.
will maintain adequate minute volume if his or her respiratory rate stays the same.
front.question: If a patient with a chest injury only inhales small amounts of air per breath, he or she:

cards.back: must increase his or her respiratory rate to maintain adequate minute volume.

choices: is less prone to penetrating trauma.
descends below the level of the navel.
might rise as high as the nipple line.
front.question: When a person is lying supine at the end of exhalation, the diaphragm:

cards.back: might rise as high as the nipple line.

choices: at least half of one lung has completely collapsed.
air is escaping into the chest wall from a damaged lung.
your patient is experiencing a pericardial tamponade.
blood is slowly accumulating within the tissue of the lung.
front.question: Subcutaneous emphysema is an indication that:
front.source: See Complications and Management of Chest Injuries

cards.back: air is escaping into the chest wall from a damaged lung.

choices: a segment of the chest wall is detached from the thoracic cage.
more than three ribs are fractured on the same side of the chest.
a segment of fractured ribs bulges during the inhalation phase.
multiple ribs are fractured on both sides of the thoracic cage.
front.question: A flail chest occurs when:
front.source: See Complications and Management of Chest Injuries

cards.back: a segment of the chest wall is detached from the thoracic cage.

front.question: The thoracic cavity is separated from the abdominal cavity by the:

choices: accumulation of air between the lungs.
blood collection within the pleural space.
blood collection within the lung tissue.
accumulation of air in the pleural space.
front.question: Pneumothorax is defined as:
front.source: See Complications and Management of Chest Injuries

cards.back: accumulation of air in the pleural space.

front.question: Irritation or damage to the pleural surfaces that causes sharp chest pain during inhalation is called:
Elevation of the rib cage during inhalation occurs when:
When assessing a patient with a hemothorax, you will most likely find:
front.source: See Complications and Management of Chest Injuries

front.question: The ________ nerves supply the diaphragm.
Signs and symptoms of a tension pneumothorax include all of the following, except:
front.source: See Complications and Management of Chest Injuries

front.question: Hemoptysis is defined as:

choices: a fractured rib that perforates the tissue of the lung surface.
extreme pleural pressure that causes the lung to rupture.
an open chest wound through which air moves during breathing.
the entry of air into the pleural space from a perforated lung.
front.question: An open pneumothorax is:
front.source: See Complications and Management of Chest Injuries

cards.back: an open chest wound through which air moves during breathing.

choices: take a series of deep breaths.
prefer to lie in a supine position.
front.question: Patients with rib fractures will commonly:
front.source: See Complications and Management of Chest Injuries
